title: Bankers Advising Fed Board Describe Libra as a Monetary Threat
text:
(Bloomberg) -- The Federal Reserve asked some of the nation’s biggest banks about Libra, the digital currency proposed by Facebook Inc., and the answer was simple: They don’t like it.

“Facebook is potentially creating a digital monetary ecosystem outside of sanctioned financial markets -- or a ‘shadow banking’ system,” banks said, according to minutes of this month’s Federal Advisory Council meeting. “As consumers adopt Libra, more deposits could migrate onto the platform, effectively reducing liquidity, and that disintermediation may further expand into loan and investment services.”

Fed Chairman Jerome Powell and Vice Chairman of Supervision Randal Quarles have warned that Facebook’s digital currency would face high standards of oversight if it launched. Members of the U.S. Congress have also voiced opposition.

In Europe, several regulators have all but ruled it out. “A core element of state sovereignty is the issuance of a currency,” German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz said earlier this month. “We will not allow private companies to do it.”

The U.S. bank executives who advise the Fed listed numerous risks of Libra and similar “stablecoins,” which are pegged to an underlying value such as one or more currencies. They included potential decreases in demand-deposit accounts and bank payment volumes, and a “possible challenge to the bank business model built on privacy.”

The bankers also noted at the quarterly meeting that Facebook’s proposal could have implications for national monetary policy, citing the “potential to reduce the ability of states to monitor, manage and influence local economies,” the bankers said.

The Federal Advisory Council is a rotating group of 12 bank executives that advise Fed Board members on economic and financial topics. It was established at the suggestion of Woodrow Wilson, the U.S. president who signed the Federal Reserve Act into law in 1913.

Members this year include chief executive officers Rene Jones of M&T Bank Corp., Beth Mooney of KeyCorp, and Brian Moynihan of Bank of America Corp.
